instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: Trying to repair TBT, in-board trace damaged?
threads.message:
Working on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that I've already spent an hour on fixing various things. The only issue left is that Thunderbolt isn't working because the probe-point for pin 6 of <CHIP>U3220</CHIP> has eroded away completely, and it's part of a through-board trace. No biggie, I thought I'd just run a wire from pin 6 of <CHIP>U3220</CHIP> to <RESISTOR>R2885</RESISTOR> pin 2. I did this, and it still doesn't work. The trace on the probe-point for pin 6 is 100% gone. I can't even see any of the trace head to possibly attach a wire. <RESISTOR>R2885</RESISTOR> is the only other place on the board this signal appears, and it doesn't seem to work when I run a wire there.

Am I out of luck on this one? Any other solutions that I'm not aware of? Any advice appreciated.

threads.title: Trying to repair TBT, in-board trace damaged?
threads.message: Probably more wrong than just that broken trace. You probably know what I think of Thunderbolt.....

threads.title: Trying to repair TBT, in-board trace damaged?
threads.message: Yeah, I hear you duke. I'll not waste time trying to get TBT working; at least I got the board back to life! Better than nothing--thanks!
